Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The team awaits a clarification before progressing with a shared task.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A social media post about your cause is currently going viral, and now is the perfect moment to add a comment with more information.
Story: My phone buzzes with a flurry of notifications as I sit at my desk, half-finished coffee cooling beside my laptop. In my inbox, a string of messages from my team grows longer—everyone is waiting for my clarification on a key detail before they can move forward with our project. I know they’re counting on me to respond quickly, to keep things moving. At the same time, my activist group’s latest post is exploding online. This is the moment we’ve been waiting for—thousands of people are reading, sharing, asking questions. If I jump in now, I can steer the conversation, answer doubts, and maybe even inspire real change. But every second I spend crafting the perfect comment is a second my colleagues are left hanging, their work stalled. My mind races, torn between the urgent pull of my team’s expectations and the rare, fleeting chance to make a difference for my cause. My fingers hover over the keyboard, heart pounding, as I try to decide which part of myself to answer first.
